As you have likely heard, 2020 is a census year. The data that the federal government collects during a census shapes where and how money will be distributed in the United States for the next 10 years. It impacts funding received for important programs like school lunches, special education, and support for teachers, as well as highway infrastructure, healthcare funding, etc. We strongly encourage families in the district to take the time to fill out the 2020 Census. It only takes about ten minutes and the easiest way to do so is online at https://my2020census.gov/.

For more information on the impact of the Census, go to https://2020census.gov/en/community-impact.html

Be Safe,
Brian

post_text: We are continually amazed at how the Triton community is stepping up to help in any way they can in these stressful times. Recently, high school teachers Kathy Norton and Scott Dube received a request to use their classroom 3D printers to print Respirator Masks to be shipped to Massachusetts General Hospital. Both teachers retrieved their printers from the high school and set them up at home. Ms. Norton, with the help of her Triton 8th-grade son, Benjamin, have printed 5 masks over the course of 3 days. Each mask has 3 parts and takes approximately 7 hours total to print. Mr. Dube has also printed masks. Yesterday, 5 masks were shipped to Dr. Tran at MGH. Ms. Norton said she will continue to print masks as long as they are accepted. Thank you, Kathy, Benjamin and Scott. Your efforts are so appreciated.

Good Afternoon,

As we navigate through the challenges that this current closure presents, there are many factors contributing to what student learning can and should look like. As a public education institution, our charge is to provide a Free and Appropriate Education (FAPE) for all students. With the schools closed, the only opportunity for learning is the ‚Äòdistance‚Äô model. While access to technology and the internet is an obvious challenge in a distance learning model, the range of academic abilities and disabilities presents the most difficult obstacles to overcome.

To that end, we have established expectations for enrichment opportunities that will keep our students engaged and supported by their teachers and other educators. We have posted what parents can expect in regards to academic support from Triton educators during the closure on our website at https://www.tritonschools.org/#tab-id-2.

As always, if there are any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to me directly at Brian.Forget@tritonschools.org.

Regards,
Brian

We would like to thank our partners in this project Youth Service America, Mott Foundation, Corporation for National and Community Service and Salem Five for making this day possible! Go Triton!
